titleStmt.title: Artificial light at night interacts with predatory threat to alter reef fish metabolite profiles

affiliation.orgName: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)
Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)
Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)

analytic.title: Artificial light at night interacts with predatory threat to alter reef fish metabolite profiles

biblStruct.note: Received 13 October 2020 Received in revised form 7 December 2020 Accepted 9 December 2020

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Anthropogenic impacts Pollution Metabolomics Predator Mesocosm

abstract.p: Light cycles and predatory threat define activity patterns (e.g. feeding/sleeping, activity/rest) in most diurnal fish species. Artificial light at night (ALAN) may disrupt natural cycles and biochemical processes, a mismatch which can eventually reduce condition and fitness. We evaluate the separate and joint effects of ALAN and predator threat on metabolism within brain, liver and muscle tissue of a common, wild caught damselfish, blue green chromis (Chromis viridis). The effects of ALAN varied according to tissue type and predator exposure. In all tissues we observed changes in metabolic pathways associated with increased activity under continuous light (despite provision of shelter), specifically those associated with energy metabolism, cell signalling, responses to oxidative stress and markers of cellular damage. In both the brain and liver tissues, predator threat served to moderate the influence of ALAN on metabolic change, likely due to increased sheltering behaviour. However, no interaction of predator threat with ALAN was observed in metabolism of the muscle tissue. Our results highlight complex sub-acute effects of ALAN exposure on tissue specific and whole organism energy metabolism. Collectively these effects indicate that ALAN has significant scope to reduce fitness of coastal fishes and potentially threaten ecosystem services, but that these changes are highly complex and may be altered by biotic drivers of activity.

div.head: H I G H L I G H T S
div.p: • Light pollution is increasing in coastal areas, combining with natural biotic drivers of activity, such as predator threat • Metabolomics is a powerful tool to study the effects of complex environmental change • We characterise separate and joint effects of artificial light and predator exposure using tissue-specific metabolomics • Artificial light exposure altered tissue metabolism, however when combined with predator cues effects were largely moderated • Our outputs highlight how abiotic and biotic drivers of activity interact to alter metabolism and organism fitness

div.head: G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
div.p: a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Anthropogenic light pollution has drastically altered nocturnal landscapes (Smith, 2008). Light pollution is estimated to double in coastal Science of the Total Environment 769 (2021) 144482areas by 2060 (e.g. associated with urbanization, harbours, hotels) (Cinzano et al., 2001;Kyba et al., 2017b), and biological impacts of artificial light at night (ALAN) are now recognized as a global research priority (Gaston et al., 2015;Davies and Smyth, 2017). ALAN alters natural light regimes in terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems and can affect light sensitive processes and behaviours (reviewed in Longcore and Rich, 2004). Cycles of light and dark also set the circadian clock, which aligns biochemical and behavioural processes (such as foraging, reproduction, migration) (Green et al., 2008;Bass and Takahashi, 2010). Mismatches in these cycles can be costly over time with long-term fitness implications (Scheer et al., 2009;Lucassen et al., 2016). Characterizing daily changes in energy metabolism (which is highly variable) is challenging, however metabolomics (and other systems biology) approaches can offer detailed insight (see for instance Dallmann et al., 2012;S.K. Davies et al., 2014).

Many reef fish species are diurnal: they are active visual feeders during the day, with an inactive phase, sheltering from predators at night (Helfman, 1986). Predator detection is typically via a combination of visual and chemical cues (Hartman and Abrahams, 2000). Brighter nights (either from a full moon, or from ALAN) may increase foraging opportunities for diurnal feeders (Shima and Swearer, 2019;Shima et al., 2020). However, the benefits of feeding at night must be balanced against increased predation risks, which will be greater for smaller fish (Milinski, 1986;Helfman, 1989;Lima and Bednekoff, 1999), and risks that may also be influenced by ALAN (Longcore and Rich, 2004). ALAN can therefore alter feeding activity in fish (Becker et al., 2013;Bolton et al., 2017), drive changes in daily activity patterns and oxygen consumption (Pulgar et al., 2019), and alter hormone and gene expression (Brüning et al., 2015;Brüning et al., 2016).

ALAN associated with urbanization may contribute to small increases in illumination in adjacent coastal habitats up to a kilometre away (Schirmer et al., 2019). More localized sources of ALAN (e.g., downlighting attached to over-water structures; Fig. 1) represent a more intense modification and likely disruptor and are the focus of our study. Here, we evaluate: i) how localized ALAN affects energy metabolism in a reef associated fish; and ii) how secondary cues, such as predatory threat, interact with ALAN to induce further changes in metabolism.

div.head: Study species and system
div.p: We evaluate the effects of ALAN on a small planktivorous reef fish, Chromis viridis on the island of Mo'orea, French Polynesia (17°30′S; 145°50′W). C. viridis (hereafter, "chromis") is a common fish species on coral reefs throughout the Indo-Pacific (Allen, 1991). Chromis typically form social aggregations, and group living reduces the metabolic rate of individuals (presumably through shared vigilance to potential predators; Nadler et al., 2016). Both juvenile and adult chromis form strong associations with branching corals of the genus Pocillopora (Lecchini et al., 2005;Pratchett et al., 2012), and individuals routinely use these corals as a refuge from predators during the day, and as a sheltering site at night. We used small colonies of Pocillopora meandrina (ca. cm dia) as standardized habitat units for chromis in our study. We used the arc-eye hawkfish (Paracirrhites arcatus), a common mesopredator, in our system as our representative predator cue (described in Section 2.2). Paracirrhites spp. use coral colonies such as P. meandrina as a hunting ground (DeMartini, 1996) and feed on a range of small prey, including crustaceans, molluscs and small fishes, including Chromis spp. (Randall et al., 1990;Leray et al., 2012).

div.head: Mesocosm design
div.p: We established eight mesocosms at the University of California's Gump Research Station and used these to evaluate the separate and joint effects ALAN and a predator cue on tissue specific metabolic profiles of chromis. Each mesocosm consisted of a standardized unit of habitat (P. meandrina) placed in the centre of a 1000 L tank. Each tank was supplied with continuous, unfiltered flow-through sea water (ca. 2 L min −1 ) supplied from Cooks Bay (long term water quality monitoring data for this site is available at Moorea Coral Reef Long Term Ecological Research (LTER): http://mcr.lternet.edu/). Tanks were covered with shade cloth (55% light reduction), and coral colonies were left to acclimate for one week, and appeared healthy (i.e. not bleached or pale) prior to the introduction of fish.

We collected chromis from the northern lagoon using a clove oil anaesthetic and a hand net, and assigned five individuals to each mesocosm (via haphazard assignment, stratified by fish lengths, to achieve a similar size distribution across tanks). Fish were left undisturbed to acclimate for h, and were observed feeding from the unfiltered water supply, and behaving normally during this time (i.e., no supplemental feeding of chromis was required).

Following the chromis acclimation period, we installed a stainlesssteel mesh predator enclosure (ca. 1 m 3 , n = 8) to the periphery of each mesocosm. We randomly assigned half of our mesocosms to a 'predator cue' treatment, and added a representative predator (P. arcatus) to the predator enclosure within the corresponding tank; the remaining four mesocosms comprised empty predatory enclosures, the control for this treatment. Predators were maintained on a diet of fresh fish pieces during the experimental period; following each feeding, excess food was immediately removed from the mesocosm.

We established an ALAN treatment orthogonal to the predator treatment. Lit tanks were subjected to ALAN for 12 h (1800 h-0600 h) for the duration of the experimental trial. Each lit tank was illuminated via a 100 w white halogen outdoor bulb (widely available in local hardware stores and mounted above the tank, producing ca. 100 lx) ( Fig. 1D). Light levels were equivalent to a dark overcast day (full daylight 10,000-25,000 lx) and exceeded that of a full moon (0.05-0.3 lx) (Schlyter, 2006;Kyba et al., 2017a).

Unlit tanks were covered with plastic tarpaulins for the same period, to prevent light overspill from illuminated tanks (Fig. 1D). Our factorial design therefore consisted of 2 replicate mesocosms per treatment combination (lit + predator; unlit + predator; lit + no predator; unlit + no predator). We repeated this factorial design in three separate trials (each trial duration was 7 nights), to achieve an overall sample size of 6 per treatment combination. We cleaned mesocosms thoroughly between trials. We used newly collected chromis, and re-randomized assignments of treatments to mesocosms in each trial.

After seven nights of exposure to the factorial treatments, chromis from all tanks were sampled at midday. Chromis were slowly corralled with a small mesh gill net into an area of the tank. Individual fish were then caught with a hand net and placed in a whirl-pak (Nasco, Fort Atkinson, WI, USA). Fish were then immediately and humanely killed via cold shock (as per VUW animal ethics committee approval 22038). Samples were stored at −80°C until processing and analysis. For this study, we randomly subsampled a single individual from each replicate mesocosm to process for untargeted metabolite analysis (final n = 6 fish per treatment).

div.head: Sample processing for metabolite extraction and GC-MS analysis
div.p: Working on dry ice, individual chromis were removed and measured for total length (TL), standard length and width. They were then rinsed with chilled ultrapure milli-Q water (MQ), blotted dry and weighed. Condition index (CI) of each fish was calculated via a regression of the log TL and log weight (Froese, 2006).

Chromis were then dissected to remove the target tissues comprising liver, brain and caudal peduncle (predominately muscle tissue, hereafter 'muscle') (with scalpel blades cleaned with 80% ethanol between collections). Finally, dissected fish were sexed based on gonad appearance. Tissue samples were then immediately frozen at −80°C and freeze dried (VirTis Benchtop K; Global Science, Auckland, New Zealand). Once completely dry, each tissue sample was weighed to determine the sample dry weight.

Metabolite extraction and GC-MS analysis was undertaken by Metabolomics Australia (MA). Solvents and chemicals were a minimum of premium grade and sourced from Merck (Macquarie Park, Australia), except for chloroform (RCI Labscan, Gillman, Australia). For muscle tissue, skin and scales were removed and a sub-sample of muscle tissue (11 mg ± 0.44 S.D.) was transferred to 2 mL cryo-mill tubes (Lysing Matrix D; MP Biomedicals, Seven Hills, Australia) with 600 μL of extraction solvent comprising chloroform:methanol:water (1:

Methanol contained 2% internal standard 13 C 6 -Sorbitol/ C 15 N-Valine. Samples were then homogenized using a cryomill (Bertin Technologies) using 6100 rpm 3 × 45 s × 45 s pause at −10°C. Samples were then mixed on a thermomixer at 950 rpm for 15 min at 30°C and centrifuged for 10 min at 13,000 rpm (18,213g). The supernatant was then transferred to a fresh tube and retained. The pellet was then re-extracted with 400 μL of the same solvent mix. The samples were vortexed for 20 s and centrifuged for 10 min at 13,000 rpm (18,213g). The two supernatant fractions were then combined and centrifuged for 5 min at 13,000 rpm (18,213g).

For liver (5 mg ± 1.54 S.D.) and brain (11 mg ± 3.25 S.D.) whole tissues were used, with total extraction volumes altered according to sample dry weight. Total extraction volume was 100 μL mg −1 dry weight tissue, with a ratio of 2:1 between extraction volume 1 and 2. Aliquots (brain 70 μL; liver 150 μL; muscle 80 μL) were then dried in a speedvac without heating.

Samples were derivatized online via a Gerstel multipurpose autosampler, and analysed with a 7890A Agilent gas chromatograph and a 5975C Agilent quadrupole mass spectrometer detector (Agilent, Santa Clara, USA), with standard settings as per De Souza (2013); Hill and Roessner (2013). Splitless and split (1:20) injections (1 μL) were undertaken for each sample. Samples were divided by tissue type into three analytical sequence batches (liver, muscle, brain). Each sequence batch was run separately, and comprised two sample blanks, four mixed sugar standards quality control (QC) samples and two instrument quality control (IQCs) samples. Additionally, four tissue-specific pooled biological quality controls (PBQCs) were run per batch at eightsample intervals.

div.head: Data analysis
div.p: Chromatograms and mass spectra were evaluated using Agilent MassHunter Quantitative Analysis version B.07.00 software. Mass spectra of eluting compounds were identified using the commercial mass spectra library NIST v17 (http://www.nist.gov), the public domain mass spectra library, Golm (Max Planck Institute of Molecular Plant Physiology, Germany) (http://csbdb.mpimp-golm.mpg.de/ csbdb/dbma/msri.html) and the in-house Metabolomics Australia mass spectral library. Sugars and sugar alcohols were identified using in-house sugar standard mixes that were run with each batch, providing level one confirmed structures by reference standard, as per the Metabolomics Standards Initiative (Fiehn et al., 2007;Schymanski et al., 2014). Individual metabolite abundances were normalized to peak areas of the internal standard C 6 -Sorbitol and dry weight (muscle tissue).

Normalized metabolite data for each tissue type (brain, liver and muscle) were then imported into SIMCA (v16.0.2) for multivariate data analysis. Metabolite data were auto scaled and log transformed (where appropriate). Given inherent variability in the data set supervised multivariate regression, partial least squaresdiscriminant analysis (PLS-DA) was conducted to investigate key metabolite features in each tissue and treatment using the following classes: dark no predator (DN) (reference group); dark predator (DP); artificial light no predator (LN); artificial light predator (LP). Variable Importance Projection (VIP) scores (>1) from each model were then used to identify key compounds.

The interaction of light and predator was then further explored for key compounds in each tissue type using a two-way ANOVA of light treatment (dark, light), predator effect (no predator, predator) and the interaction of light and predator (light * predator) conducted in GraphPad Prism (v8.4.3). The analyses were corrected for multiple comparisons by controlling the False Discovery Rate via the two-stage step up (Benjamini et al., 2006).

The effects of covariates (fish TL and CI) on key metabolites in each tissue type were then explored with multivariate GLM; fixed effects, light (light, dark), predator (predator, no predator) and the interaction (light * predator). Any differences in covariates of TL and CI between trials and treatment groups were explored with one-way ANOVA, with Fisher's Least Significant Difference (LSD) posthoc test using IBM SPSS (v27).

div.head: Results
div.p: Chromis used in this study ranged from 48 to 74 mm in length (mean TL=61.25 mm, SD=7.72) and had a roughly equal ratio of males to females (11:13) ( Table A1). Mean TL and condition did not vary between treatment groups (TL; one-way ANOVA, F (3, 20) = 1.251, p = 0.318; CI; one-way ANOVA, F (3, 20) = 0.899, p = 0.459). However, TL and condition of analysed fish differed between trials (1-3) (oneway ANOVA, F (3, 20) = 7.391, p = 0.004) (one-way ANOVA, F (3, 20) = 6.262, p = 0.007), contributing to high within treatment group variability in the metabolite data set (see tissue specific analyses below). Though the covariates analysed (TL and CI) did not exert any significant influence on treatment effect in any tissue type (multivariate GLM; Tables A2-4).

div.head: Effects of ALAN and predator cues on brain tissue metabolite profiles
div.p: A significant effect of light treatment was found on abundances of individual metabolites, with ALAN resulting in an increased pool size of organic acids, citrate (+20%), benzoic acid (+11%), pyroglutamate (+12%); amino acid, valine (+3%); and sugar phosphate, glycerol-3-phosphate (+25%); no significant individual effect of predator was observed (two-way ANOVA, Table A5; Fig. 2A).

The interaction of predator with light resulted in a more widespread and altered effect of light treatment (to more closely resemble dark groups), specifically a negative interaction and decline in pool size of amino acids and amides, valine, leucine, isoleucine, aspartic acid, butyro-1,4-lactam; organic acid, gluconate-6-phosphate; sugar phosphate, inositol-1-phosphate; purine and pyrimidine derivatives, uracil, hypoxanthine and inosine ( Fig. 2A). As viewed in the spread of samples in the PLS-DA scores plot for all treatment groups, the metabolite pools of the combined treatment (LP) showed high similarity to dark treatment groups (DN, DP) (Fig. 2B).

The interaction of predator effect with light (LN vs LP) returned the strongest predicative model of tissue types and treatments, with significant separation of treatment groups (R2X(cum) = 0.809, R2Y(cum) = 0.995, Q2(cum) = 0.823) (Fig. 2C, Table A8).

div.head: Effects of ALAN and predator cues on liver tissue metabolite profiles
div.p: ALAN and predator treatments alone resulted in fewer consistent effects in the liver, however a significant decline (−28%) was observed in pools of the fatty acid derivative, 2-monopalmitoylglycerol with predator treatment, irrespective of light (two-way ANOVA, F(1, 20) = 4.404, p = 0.0488; Table A6, Fig. 3A).

More widespread change in the relative abundance of individual metabolites was observed with the interaction of light and predator treatments; pools of the ketone body, 3-hydroxybutyric acid, showed a negative interaction, whereas the amino acid, glycine, and the sugar phosphate, glucose-6-phosphate, both showed a positive interaction of light and predator treatment (Fig. 3A, Table A6).

The liver produced relatively weak predictive models for any interaction of light with predator treatment, the PLS-DA model for all treatment groups showed no separation of the combined treatment group (LP), with dark controls (DN, DP) ( Fig. 3B, Table A9), with the strongest model DN vs LP (R2X(cum)= 0.338, R2Y(cum)=0.858, Q2(cum)= 0.107) (Table A9). When the ALAN groups alone are compared, the LP group was characterized by elevated pools of the sugar phosphate, fructose-6-phosphate, and the amino acid derivatives pyroglutamate and glutamate (Fig. 3A).

div.head: Effects of ALAN and predator cues on muscle tissue metabolite profiles
div.p: A significant effect of light treatment was found on abundances of individual metabolites, ALAN resulted in consistent pool size reductions of amino acids, alanine (−19%), glycine (−27%), threonine (−25%), serine (−27%); predator effect resulted in increased pools of the pyrimidine, uracil (+29%) (two-way ANOVA, Table A7; Fig. 4A). The interaction of predator with light resulted only in a negative response for the amino acid, valine.

The PLS-DA model for all treatment groups showed no separation of the combined treatment group (LP) and light predator free group (LN) (Fig. 4B, Table A10). However, most variation in the muscle data set was explained by a combination of light and predator (LP), versus dark predator free groups (DN), producing the strongest predicative model (R2X(cum) = 0.591, R2Y(cum) = 0.991, Q2(cum) = 0.656) (Fig. 4C). Light and predator treatment groups were also characterized by elevated pools of the purine breakdown product uric acid, coupled to smaller pools of pyroglutamate and malate versus the dark control ( Fig. 4A).

div.head: Increased brain activity under ALAN is moderated by predatory cues
div.p: Light treatment resulted in accumulations (3-25%) of central energy metabolites, such as TCA cycle intermediates, associated organic acids and amino acids (including citrate, valine), coupled to altered pools of glycolysis (glycerol-3-phosphate) and pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) intermediates (gluconate-6-phosphate). We also observed accumulations of multiple products associated with cellular damage, degradation and signalling pathways (such as pyroglutamate, hypoxanthine, inositol-1-phosphate). Change was indicative of altered energy requirements in the brain, likely associated with increased activity under continuous light. However predatory threat served to moderate the influences of ALAN to free metabolite pools, with the predator treatment group more closely reflecting dark treatments.

In fish, light cues stimulate photoreceptors in the pineal gland and retina, inhibiting the production of the hormone melatonin. Melatonin levels in turn act as internal chronometer for tissues, in combination with behaviour cycles (activity/rest, feeding/fasting) (Plano et al., 2017;Sánchez-Vázquez et al., 2019). Altered patterns of light and activity can therefore cause conflicting internal signals and modified metabolic cycles in central and peripheral tissues (Sánchez-Vázquez et al., 2019). Overall, brain metabolism in teleost (bony) fish as with other vertebrates, is typically fuelled via the oxidation of glucose (or its intermediates, such as pyruvate and lactate), levels of which are tightly regulated (Soengas and Aldegunde, 2002). However, each cell type will have a distinct metabolite profile; in the astrocytes (which regulate the transmission of electrical impulses within the brain) lactate producing, aerobic glycolysis predominates (Magistretti and Allaman, 2015). Lactate may also play a key cell signalling role (Magistretti and Allaman, 2018) and elevated lactate levels (n.s. trend observed here, Fig. 2A) have been suggested as an ideal sleep/wakefulness biomarker (Naylor et al., 2012). In contrast, brain neurons cannot upregulate glycolysis, as such glucose is mainly processed through the oxidative branch of the PPP (Magistretti and Allaman, 2015). The PPP is also critical to the regeneration of reduced glutathione and the scavenging of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the neurons (Magistretti and Allaman, 2015). Further accumulations of degradation products, such as the purine derivative, hypoxanthine, and antioxidant intermediates (pyroglutamate) are indicative of increased cellular damage, likely under conditions of increased activity and responses to oxidative stress.

The addition of a predator served to moderate ALAN effects on brain metabolism. Although we did not record activity, it may be that predatory cues and predator threat served to moderate feeding and tank exploration at night in ALAN treated groups. Chromis spp. typically exhibit diurnal behaviour, forming small, highly organized social groups, which feed on plankton during the day and shelter in coral at night (Helfman, 1986). As visual feeders, exposure to continuous light would increase feeding opportunity into the night, and therefore associated change to metabolic cycles and signals in central tissues (such as the brain) and those of peripheral tissues (liver and muscle). Whereas predatory cues may have served to increase sheltering at night and therefore limit this additional activity, to more closely resemble natural diurnal behaviour.

div.head: ALAN and predatory cues interact to alter peripheral cycles and signals in the liver
div.p: The predictive power of the liver-specific models was poor, though significant effects of ALAN to free metabolite pools were still observed in this key metabolic tissue. Under conditions of night lighting alone (LN), we observed elevated pools of compounds associated with increased turnover of alternative energy metabolism, antioxidant and cellular signal pathways. These responses were moderated in the combined light and predator exposed group (LP). Specifically, we observed a significant negative interaction of light and predator treatment for the ketone body, 3-hydroxybutyric acid, versus a positive interaction for compounds associated with the PPP (glucose-6-phopshate, fructose-6-phosphate), antioxidant intermediates (pyroglutamate, glutamate) and the amino acid, glycine (glutamate precursor).

In the lit predator free treatment (LN) we observed accumulations of the ketone body, 3-hydroxybutyric acid, a by-product of fatty acid catabolism (beta oxidation). Further the fatty acid derivative, 2-monopalmitoylglycerol was also elevated in the LN group, indicative of increased alternative energy generation (such as via gluconeogenesis). Both gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis in the liver are strongly regulated by the circadian clock (Rui, 2014). The molecular clock regulates key, often rate-limiting, enzymes that are involved in the metabolism of glucose, proteins and lipids (Hastings et al., 2003). In mammals the clocks of peripheral tissues are not intrinsically light sensitive and so, rely on signals from the central system and activity cycles, such as feeding to match behaviour (Hastings et al., 2003). Ornithine a non-protein amino acid and urea cycle intermediate (n.s. trend observed here, Fig. 3A) is one such metabolite known to affect peripheral clocks and associated gene expression (Fukuda et al., 2016). In fish however, peripheral tissues may also be directly light entrained (such as via light induced molecular clocks) (Cahill, 2002). As such change to peripheral metabolic and signalling cycles, such as ornithine, are likely under conditions of continuous light and altered feeding activity. Further, predatory cues may serve to alter these feeding/activity cycles and moderate ALAN induced changes.

We also detected change to metabolites associated with a key signalling pathway, the neurotransmitter, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA). Pools of GABA-associated precursors (2-amino-butyric acid, pyroglutamate and glutamate) were smallest in the LN group. GABA is a key signalling mechanism in fish, though its precursor glutamate can also function directly (Levavi-Sivan et al., 2010). GABA and its receptors have roles that are critical to feeding behaviour (Williams and Elmquist, 2012;Snigirov and Sylantyev, 2018); reproductive development (Levavi-Sivan et al., 2010) and sleep cycles (Gottesmann, 2002). GABA receptors also function in olfactory predator detection, change in which have been shown to directly affect glucose metabolism (Schunter et al., 2018;Williams et al., 2019). As discussed above, predatory cues may elicit change in the physical activity of ALAN exposed fish (exploration of tanks and feeding at night), however it is also noteworthy that the same signalling networks involved in the detection of olfactory cues, can directly influence the activity of molecular and metabolic pathways (Schunter et al., 2018;Williams et al., 2019).

div.head: ALAN exposure alters muscle metabolism irrespective of predator cues
div.p: In contrast to other tissue types, light and dark treatments alone had the greatest effect on abundance of individual metabolites in the muscle tissue. Light exposure resulted in consistent declines in pools of glucogenic amino acids (alanine, glycine, serine, threonine, valine) and cellular antioxidants (pyroglutamate). However, predator treatment (irrespective of light treatment) resulted only in elevated pools of the pyrimidine, uracil.

The caudal peduncle of teleost fish comprises predominately glycolytic white muscle tissue and red oxidative muscle (Martínez et al., 2003). At normal slow swimming speeds the red muscle is used, with the white muscle utilized for faster bursts of speed, predator avoidance and endurance (Odell et al., 2003). Chromis spp. as with the majority of damselfishes, swim predominately with their pectoral fins at slow speeds (classed as median-paired fin gaits, MPF swimmers) (Fulton, 2007). The caudal peduncle muscles are used for accelerative behaviours, collectively termed fast starts (Domenici and Hale, 2019). Fast start swimming behaviours include feeding strikes, escape responses and social interactions (Domenici and Hale, 2019).

We did not observe significant change to lactate pools (product of glycolysis) with any treatment, suggesting that the oxidative capacity of glycolysis was not exceeded by additional activity in the white muscles. However, we did observe accumulations of the pyrimidine, uracil, with predator treatment. Uracil is associated with glycogen and protein synthesis and is a product of the breakdown of nucleotide sugars (such as UDP-glucose, a glycogen precursor) (Lecca and Ceruti, 2008). Accumulation of this critical precursor with predator treatment in the muscle tissue, was indicative of a decline in the synthesis of this storage product and/or an increase in the catabolism of associated intermediates.

With light treatment we observed changes to pools associated with oxidative pathways, specifically a decline to the relative abundance of glucogenic (glucose producing) amino acids and the cellular antioxidant, pyroglutamate. Amino acid and protein degradation in muscle tissues are not typical under normal conditions, however sustained, low level swimming activity increases protein turnover and degradation (Moyes and West, 1995). Aerobic pathways will also continuously generate reactive oxygen species as a biproduct of oxidative metabolism (Filho et al., 1993). Antioxidant pathways are therefore necessary to prevent damage associated with the generation of these highly damaging biproducts, particularly under sustained activity and in actively swimming species (Filho et al., 1993;Otto and Moon, 1996). Major mechanisms include the glutathione (GSH) cycle and antioxidants such as uric acid (Martínez-Álvarez et al., 2005). Pathway intermediates of the GSH cycle characterized dark groups, whereas light treatment groups displayed elevated pools of the purine breakdown product uric acid, indicative of change to antioxidant pathways and exposure to oxidative damage under conditions of sustained activity (e.g. increased feeding strikes and social interactions).

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: The capacity of ALAN to alter natural cycles and wide-ranging effects on light-exposed systems are of increasing concern (Longcore and Rich, 2004; T.W. Davies et al., 2014;Knop et al., 2017). Systems biology tools (such as metabolomics) offer excellent opportunities to better understand the physiological mechanisms that underpin these complex yet often subtle effects. Combining omics approaches with multifactorial manipulative experiments can help to reveal complexities (e.g., interactive effects of multiple stressors) that lead to improved mechanistic understanding and therefore management of anthropogenic impacts.

An untargeted metabolomics approach allowed us to characterize small changes in a diverse range of metabolic pathways, associated with energy metabolism, cell signalling, responses to oxidative stress and cellular damage, with potential significance for longer term impacts on condition and fitness. Given widespread and continuing increases in coastal development, there is a real need to better understand how ALAN interacts with natural and man-made drivers of behaviour and energy metabolism. Mismatches may be costly and contribute to increasing stressors on coral reef fishes.

CRediT authorship contribution statement Katie E. Hillyer: Conceptualization, Methodology, Formal analysis, Investigation, Writingoriginal draft, Visualization, Project administration, Funding acquisition. David J. Beale: Methodology, Formal analysis, Writingreview & editing. Jeffrey S. Shima: Conceptualization, Methodology, Formal analysis, Resources, Writingreview & editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition.

div.head: Declaration of competing interest
div.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: (A-C) Localized ALAN associated with overwater bungalows in Mo'orea, French Polynesia; and (D) the experimental mesocosm set up used herein, lit (n=4) and unlit (n=4) mesocosms after dark. (Photo credit K.E.H.)

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Brain tissue (A) box plots of relative abundance of key metabolites in each treatment group (with 5-95 percentile), (a) and (b) indicate significant differences between treatment groups, * indicates differences within light × treatment groups (two-way ANOVA, p < 0.05, with multiple comparisons); (B) supervised PLS-DA scores plot of metabolite data for treatment groups (component scores (t[1]) and 2 (t[2]) and variance explained by the model of X variables (R2X[1]; R2X[2]), with Hotelling ellipse (95%)): dark no predator (DN, dark blue) (reference group); dark predator (DP, light blue) (predator treatment); light no predator (LN, red) (light treatment); and light predator (LP, yellow) (light × predator) treatments; (R2X(cum) = 0.619, R2Y(cum) = 0.226, Q2(cum) = −0.0651); (C) PLS-DA for treatment groups light no predator (LN, red) (light treatment, reference) and light predator (LP, yellow) (light × predator) treatments; (R2X(cum) = 0.809, R2Y(cum) = 0.995, Q2(cum) = 0.823).

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Liver tissue A) box plots of relative abundance of key metabolites in each treatment group (with 5-95 percentile), (a) and (b) indicate significant differences between treatment groups, * indicates differences within light × treatment groups (two-way ANOVA, p < 0.05, with multiple comparisons); (B) supervised PLS-DA scores plot of metabolite data for treatment groups (component scores 1 (t[1]) and 2 (t[2]) and variance explained by the model of X variables (R2X[1]; R2X[2]), with Hotelling ellipse (95%)): dark no predator (DN, dark blue) (reference group); dark predator (DP, light blue) (predator treatment); light no predator (LN, red) (light treatment); and light predator (LP, yellow) (light × predator) treatments; (R2X(cum) = 0.277, R2Y(cum) = 0.282, Q2(cum) = −0.21); (C) PLS-DA for treatment groups light no predator (LN, red) (light treatment, reference) and light predator (LP, yellow) (light × predator) treatments; (R2X(cum) = 0.293, R2Y(cum) = 0.82, Q2(cum) = −0.21).

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Muscle tissue A) box plots of relative abundance of key metabolites in each treatment group (with 5-95 percentile), (a) and (b) indicate significant differences between treatment groups (two-way ANOVA, p < 0.05, with multiple comparisons); (B) supervised PLS-DA scores plot of metabolite data for treatment groups (component scores 1 (t[1]) and 2 (t[2]) and variance explained by the model of X variables (R2X[1]; R2X[2]), with Hotelling ellipse (95%)): dark no predator (DN, dark blue) (reference group); dark predator (DP, light blue) (predator treatment); light no predator (LN, red) (light treatment); and light predator (LP, yellow) (light × predator) treatments; (R2X(cum) = 0.353, R2Y(cum) = 0.294, Q2 (cum) = −0.178); (C) PLS-DA for treatment groups dark no predator (DN, dark blue) (dark treatment, reference) and light predator (LP, yellow) (light × predator) treatments; (R2X (cum) = 0.591, R2Y(cum) = 0.991, Q2(cum) = 0.656).

body.note: K.E. Hillyer, D.J. Beale and J.S. Shima Science of the Total Environment 769 (2021) 144482

div.head: Acknowledgement
div.p: The authors wish to thank the staff and researchers of Gump Station, University of California, particularly to Pauline Mitterwallner and Phoebe Caie who assisted with the collection and sampling of fish.

Thanks also to the technicians and staff of Metabolomics Australia at the University of Melbourne, particularly to Adrian Lutz, Kim Kwan, Siria Natera, Veronica Lui and Ute Roessner for all their assistance and expertise throughout the project.

Research grants from the Royal Society of New Zealand Marsden Fund (VUW1503, 2016-2020), the U.S. National Science Foundation (OCE-1130359), and Victoria University of Wellington provided funding (URF). Victoria University Coastal Ecology Lab and the UC Gump Research Station provided essential logistic support.
